item.name: autocommit
item.description: The autocommit mode.

item.name: automatic_sp_privileges
item.description: When this variable has a value of 1 (the default), the server automatically grants the EXECUTE and ALTER ROUTINE privileges to the creator of a stored routine, if the user cannot already execute and alter or drop the routine.

item.name: big_tables
item.description: If set to 1, all temporary tables are stored on disk rather than in memory.

item.name: Binlog_cache_disk_use
item.description: The number of transactions that used the binary log cache but that exceeded the value of binlog_cache_size and used a temporary file to store changes from the transaction.

item.name: binlog_cache_size
item.description: The size of the cache to hold changes to the binary log during a transaction.

item.name: Binlog_cache_use
item.description: The number of transactions that used the binary log cache.

item.name: binlog_direct_non_transactional_updates
item.description: Due to concurrency issues, a slave can become inconsistent when a transaction contains updates to both transactional and nontransactional tables. MySQL tries to preserve causality among these statements by writing nontransactional statements to the transaction cache, which is flushed upon commit. However, problems arise when modifications done to nontransactional tables on behalf of a transaction become immediately visible to other connections because these changes may not be written immediately into the binary log.

item.name: binlog_format
item.description: This variable sets the binary logging format, and can be any one of STATEMENT, ROW, or MIXED.

item.name: Binlog_stmt_cache_disk_use
item.description: The number of nontransaction statements that used the binary log statement cache but that exceeded the value of binlog_stmt_cache_size and used a temporary file to store those statements.

item.name: binlog_stmt_cache_size
item.description: This variable determines the size of the cache for the binary log to hold nontransactional statements issued during a transaction.

item.name: Binlog_stmt_cache_use
item.description: The number of nontransactional statements that used the binary log statement cache.

item.name: bulk_insert_buffer_size
item.description: MyISAM uses a special tree-like cache to make bulk inserts faster for INSERT ... SELECT, INSERT ... VALUES (...), (...), ..., and LOAD DATA INFILE when adding data to nonempty tables.

item.name: Bytes_received
item.description: The number of bytes received from all clients.

item.name: Bytes_sent
item.description: The number of bytes sent to all clients.

item.name: Com_admin_commands
item.description: The Com_xxx statement counter variables indicate the number of times each xxx statement has been executed. There is one status variable for each type of statement. For example, Com_delete and Com_update count DELETE and UPDATE statements, respectively. Com_delete_multi and Com_update_multi are similar but apply to DELETE and UPDATE statements that use multiple-table syntax.

item.name: concurrent_insert
item.description: If 1 (the default), MySQL permits INSERT and SELECT statements to run concurrently for MyISAM tables that have no free blocks in the middle of the data file.

item.name: Connections
item.description: The number of connection attempts (successful or not) to the MySQL server.

item.name: connect_timeout
item.description: The number of seconds that the mysqld server waits for a connect packet before responding with Bad handshake.

item.name: Created_tmp_disk_tables
item.description: The number of internal on-disk temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

item.name: Created_tmp_files
item.description: How many temporary files mysqld has created.

item.name: Created_tmp_tables
item.description: The number of internal temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

item.name: default_storage_engine
item.description: The default storage engine.

trigger.name: Default storage engine is not InnoDB

item.name: Delayed_errors
item.description: The number of rows written with INSERT DELAYED for which some error occurred (probably duplicate key).

item.name: delayed_insert_limit
item.description: After inserting delayed_insert_limit delayed rows, the INSERT DELAYED handler thread checks whether there are any SELECT statements pending. If so, it permits them to execute before continuing to insert delayed rows.

item.name: Delayed_insert_threads
item.description: The number of INSERT DELAYED handler threads in use.

item.name: delayed_insert_timeout
item.description: How many seconds an INSERT DELAYED handler thread should wait for INSERT statements before terminating.

item.name: delayed_queue_size
item.description: This is a per-table limit on the number of rows to queue when handling INSERT DELAYED statements. If the queue becomes full, any client that issues an INSERT DELAYED statement waits until there is room in the queue again.

item.name: Delayed_writes
item.description: The number of INSERT DELAYED rows written.

item.name: delay_key_write
item.description: It can have one of the following values to affect handling of the DELAY_KEY_WRITE table option that can be used in CREATE TABLE statements.

item.name: div_precision_increment
item.description: This variable indicates the number of digits by which to increase the scale of the result of division operations performed with the / operator.

item.name: engine_condition_pushdown
item.description: The engine condition pushdown optimization enables processing for certain comparisons to be "pushed down" to the storage engine level for more efficient execution. Engine condition pushdown is used only by the NDBCLUSTER storage engine.

item.name: event_scheduler
item.description: This variable indicates the status of the Event Scheduler.

item.name: expand_fast_index_creation
item.description: May also optimize index access for subsequent DML statements because using it results in much less fragmented indexes. Only for Percona!

item.name: expire_logs_days
item.description: The number of days for automatic binary log file removal.

trigger.name: Binary logs in MySQL are not set to expire

item.name: Flashcache_enabled
item.description: This status variable shows if the Flashcache support has been enabled.

item.name: flush
item.description: If ON, the server flushes (synchronizes) all changes to disk after each SQL statement.

item.name: Flush_commands
item.description: The number of times the server flushes tables, whether because a user executed a FLUSH TABLES statement or due to internal server operation. It is also incremented by receipt of a COM_REFRESH packet. This is in contrast to Com_flush, which indicates how many FLUSH statements have been executed, whether FLUSH TABLES, FLUSH LOGS, and so forth.

item.name: flush_time
item.description: If this is set to a nonzero value, all tables are closed every flush_time seconds to free up resources and synchronize unflushed data to disk. This option is best used only on systems with minimal resources.

item.name: foreign_key_checks
item.description: Foreign key constraints for InnoDB tables are checked or not.

item.name: ft_max_word_len
item.description: The maximum length of the word to be included in a FULLTEXT index.

item.name: ft_min_word_len
item.description: The minimum length of the word to be included in a FULLTEXT index.

item.name: ft_query_expansion_limit
item.description: The number of top matches to use for full-text searches performed using WITH QUERY EXPANSION.

item.name: general_log
item.description: Whether the general query log is enabled.

item.name: group_concat_max_len
item.description: The maximum permitted result length in bytes for the GROUP_CONCAT() function.

item.name: have_compress
item.description: YES if the zlib compression library is available to the server, NO if not.

item.name: have_crypt
item.description: YES if the crypt() system call is available to the server, NO if not.

item.name: have_csv
item.description: YES if mysqld supports CSV tables, NO if not.

item.name: have_dynamic_loading
item.description: YES if mysqld supports dynamic loading of plugins, NO if not.

item.name: have_geometry
item.description: YES if the server supports spatial data types, NO if not.

item.name: have_innodb
item.description: YES if mysqld supports InnoDB tables.

item.name: have_ndbcluster
item.description: YES if mysqld supports NDBCLUSTER tables.

item.name: have_partitioning
item.description: YES if mysqld supports partitioning.

item.name: have_profiling
item.description: YES if statement profiling capability is present, NO if not.

item.name: have_query_cache
item.description: YES if mysqld supports the query cache, NO if not.

item.name: have_rtree_keys
item.description: YES if RTREE indexes are available, NO if not. (These are used for spatial indexes in MyISAM tables.)

item.name: have_ssl
item.description: YES if mysqld supports SSL connections, NO if not.

item.name: have_symlink
item.description: YES if symbolic link support is enabled, NO if not.

trigger.name: Symlinks are enabled in MySQL Server

item.name: hostname
item.description: The server sets this variable to the server host name at startup.

item.name: ignore_builtin_innodb
item.description: Whether the server was started with the --ignore-builtin-innodb option, which causes the server to behave as if the built-in InnoDB is not present.

item.name: Innodb_active_transactions
item.description: Amount of active transactions in InnoDB.

item.name: innodb_adaptive_flushing
item.description: InnoDB Plugin 1.0.4 and up uses a heuristic to determine when to flush dirty pages in the buffer pool. This heuristic is designed to avoid bursts of I/O activity and is used when innodb_adaptive_flushing is enabled (which is the default).

item.name: innodb_adaptive_flushing_method
item.description: This variable controls the way adaptive checkpointing is performed. Only for Percona!

item.name: Innodb_adaptive_hash_cells
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_adaptive_hash_heap_buffers
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_adaptive_hash_index
item.description: Whether the InnoDB adaptive hash index is enabled or disabled.

item.name: innodb_adaptive_hash_index_partitions
item.description: Specifies the number of partitions to use in the adaptive hash search process.

item.name: Innodb_adaptive_hash_memory
item.description: Shows the size of the InnoDB adaptive hash index.

item.name: Innodb_adaptive_hash_non_hash_searches
item.description: Non-hash searches as shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_additional_mem_pool_size
item.description: The size in bytes of a memory pool InnoDB uses to store data dictionary information and other internal data structures.

item.name: innodb_autoextend_increment
item.description: The increment size (in MB) for extending the size of an auto-extending shared tablespace file when it becomes full.

item.name: innodb_autoinc_lock_mode
item.description: The locking mode to use for generating auto-increment values. The permissible values are 0, 1, or 2, for “traditional”, “consecutive”, or “interleaved” lock mode, respectively.

item.name: Innodb_background_log_sync
item.description: As shown in the BACKGROUND THREAD section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_blocking_buffer_pool_restore
item.description: If set to 1 (0 is default), XtraDB will wait until the LRU dump is completely restored upon restart before reporting back to the server that it has successfully started up. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_buffer_pool_instances
item.description: If innodb_buffer_pool_size is set to more than 1GB, innodb_buffer_pool_instances divides the InnoDB buffer pool into this many instances. The default is 1, but for large systems with buffer pools of many gigabytes, many instances can help reduce contention concurrency. Each instance manages its own data structures and takes an equal portion of the total buffer pool size, so for example if innodb_buffer_pool_size is 4GB and innodb_buffer_pool_instances is set to 4, each instance will be 1GB. Each instance should ideally be at least 1GB in size. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_data
item.description: Number of InnoDB buffer pool pages which contain data, both dirty (modified) and clean (unmodified).

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_dirty
item.description: Number of InnoDB buffer pool pages which contain dirty (modified) data.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_flushed
item.description: Number of InnoDB buffer pool pages which have been flushed.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_free
item.description: Number of free InnoDB buffer pool pages.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_LRU_flushed
item.description: Flush list as shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_made_not_young
item.description: Pages not young as shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_made_young
item.description: Pages made young as shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_misc
item.description: The number of pages that are busy because they have been allocated for administrative overhead such as row locks or the adaptive hash index.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_old
item.description: Old database page, as shown in the BUFFER POOL AND MEMORY section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_pages_total
item.description: Total number of InnoDB buffer pool pages.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_reads
item.description: The number of logical reads that InnoDB could not satisfy from the buffer pool, and had to read directly from the disk.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_read_ahead
item.description: The number of pages read into the InnoDB buffer pool by the read-ahead background thread.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_read_ahead_evicted
item.description: The number of pages read into the InnoDB buffer pool by the read-ahead background thread that were subsequently evicted without having been accessed by queries.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_read_ahead_rnd
item.description: The number of “random” read-aheads initiated by InnoDB. This happens when a query scans a large portion of a table but in random order.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_read_requests
item.description: The number of logical read requests InnoDB has done.

item.name: innodb_buffer_pool_restore_at_startup
item.description: Time in seconds between automatic buffer pool dumps. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_buffer_pool_size
item.description: InnoDB buffer pool size in bytes.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_wait_free
item.description: Normally, writes to the InnoDB buffer pool happen in the background. However, if it is necessary to read or create a page and no clean pages are available, it is also necessary to wait for pages to be flushed first. This counter counts instances of these waits. If the buffer pool size has been set properly, this value should be small.

item.name: Innodb_buffer_pool_write_requests
item.description: The number writes done to the InnoDB buffer pool.

item.name: innodb_change_buffering
item.description: Whether InnoDB performs change buffering, an optimization that delays write operations to secondary indexes so that the I/O operations can be performed sequentially.

item.name: Innodb_checkpoint_age
item.description: The checkpoint age, as shown in the LOG section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_checkpoint_age_target
item.description: The maximum value of the checkpoint age. Only for Percona and MariaDB! Removed: MariaDB 10.0/XtraDB 5.6 - replaced with InnoDB flushing method from MySQL 5.6.

item.name: Innodb_checkpoint_max_age
item.description: Max checkpoint age, as shown in the LOG section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_checkpoint_target_age
item.description: Checkpoint age target, as shown in the LOG section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB! Removed in MariaDB 10.0/XtraDB 5.6 and replaced with MySQL 5.6's flushing implementation.

item.name: innodb_checksums
item.description: InnoDB can use checksum validation on all pages read from the disk to ensure extra fault tolerance against broken hardware or data files.

item.name: innodb_commit_concurrency
item.description: The number of threads that can commit at the same time.

item.name: innodb_concurrency_tickets
item.description: When a thread is permitted to enter InnoDB, it is given a number of “free tickets” equal to the value of innodb_concurrency_tickets, and the thread can enter and leave InnoDB freely until it has used up its tickets.

item.name: innodb_corrupt_table_action
item.description: With the default value XtraDB will intentionally crash the server with an assertion failure as it would normally do when detecting corrupted data in a single-table tablespace. Only for Percona!

item.name: Innodb_current_row_locks
item.description: Number of current row locks on InnoDB tables as shown in the TRANSACTIONS section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_current_transactions
item.description: Amount of transactions in InnoDB.

item.name: Innodb_data_fsyncs
item.description: The number of fsync() operations so far.

item.name: Innodb_data_pending_fsyncs
item.description: The current number of pending fsync() operations.

item.name: Innodb_data_pending_reads
item.description: The current number of pending reads.

item.name: Innodb_data_pending_writes
item.description: The current number of pending writes.

item.name: Innodb_data_reads
item.description: The total number of data reads.

item.name: Innodb_data_read
item.description: The amount of data read since the server was started.

item.name: Innodb_data_writes
item.description: The total number of data writes.

item.name: Innodb_data_written
item.description: The amount of data written so far, in bytes.

item.name: Innodb_dblwr_pages_written
item.description: The number of pages that have been written for doublewrite operations.

item.name: Innodb_dblwr_writes
item.description: The number of doublewrite operations that have been performed.

item.name: Innodb_deadlocks
item.description: Total number of InnoDB deadlocks. Deadlocks occur when at least two transactions are waiting for the other to finish, creating a circular dependency. InnoDB usually detects these quickly, returning an error. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_dict_size_limit
item.description: Size in bytes of a soft limit the memory used by tables in the data dictionary. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_dict_tables
item.description: Number of entries in the XtraDB data dictionary cache. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_doublewrite
item.description: If this variable is enabled (the default), InnoDB stores all data twice, first to the doublewrite buffer, and then to the actual data files.

item.name: innodb_fake_changes
item.description: Fake changes attempts to reduce this overhead by reading the rows for INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE statements but not updating them. The rollback is then very fast with little or nothing to do. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_fast_checksum
item.description: Implements a more CPU efficient XtraDB checksum algorithm, useful for write-heavy loads with high I/O. If set to 1 on a server with tables that have been created with it set to 0, reads will be slower, so tables should be recreated (dumped and reloaded). XtraDB will fail to start if set to 0 and there are tables created while set to 1. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_fast_shutdown
item.description: The InnoDB shutdown mode.

item.name: innodb_file_format
item.description: The file format to use for new InnoDB tables.

item.name: innodb_file_format_check
item.description: This variable can be set to 1 or 0 at server startup to enable or disable whether InnoDB checks the file format tag in the shared tablespace (for example, Antelope or Barracuda).

item.name: innodb_file_per_table
item.description: If innodb_file_per_table is enabled, InnoDB creates each new table using its own .ibd file for storing data and indexes, rather than in the system tablespace.

item.name: innodb_flush_method
item.description: XtraDB/InnoDB flushing method.

item.name: innodb_flush_neighbor_pages
item.description: Determines whether, when dirty pages are flushed to the data file, neighboring pages in the data file are flushed at the same time. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_force_load_corrupted
item.description: Lets InnoDB load tables at startup that are marked as corrupted.

item.name: innodb_force_recovery
item.description: The crash recovery mode.

item.name: Innodb_have_atomic_builtins
item.description: Whether the server has been built with atomic instructions, provided by the CPU ensuring that critical low-level operations can't be interrupted.

item.name: Innodb_history_list_length
item.description: History list length as shown in the TRANSACTIONS section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_ibuf_accel_rate
item.description: Allows the insert buffer activity to be adjusted. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_ibuf_active_contract
item.description: Specifies whether the insert buffer can be processed before it's full. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_discarded_deletes
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output.

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_discarded_delete_marks
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_discarded_inserts
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_free_list
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_ibuf_max_size
item.description: Maximum size in bytes of the insert buffer.

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_merged_deletes
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_merged_delete_marks
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_merged_inserts
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_merges
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_segment_size
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_ibuf_size
item.description: As shown in the INSERT BUFFER AND ADAPTIVE HASH INDEX section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_import_table_from_xtrabackup
item.description: If set to 1, permits importing of .ibd files exported with the XtraBackup --export option. Previously named innodb_expand_import.

item.name: innodb_io_capacity
item.description: An upper limit on the I/O activity performed by the InnoDB background tasks, such as flushing pages from the buffer pool and merging data from the insert buffer.

item.name: innodb_kill_idle_transaction
item.description: Time in seconds before killing an idle XtraDB transaction. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_large_prefix
item.description: Enable this option to allow index key prefixes longer than 767 bytes (up to 3072 bytes), for InnoDB tables that use the DYNAMIC and COMPRESSED row formats.

item.name: innodb_lazy_drop_table
item.description: If innodb_lazy_drop_table is set to 1 (0 is default), XtraDB attempts to optimize DROP TABLE processing by deferring the dropping of related pages from the buffer pool until there is time, only initially marking them.

item.name: innodb_locks_unsafe_for_binlog
item.description: Set to 0 by default, in which case XtraDB/InnoDB uses gap locking. If set to 1, gap locking is disabled for searches and index scans.

item.name: innodb_lock_wait_timeout
item.description: The timeout in seconds an InnoDB transaction waits for a row lock before giving up.

item.name: innodb_log_block_size
item.description: Size in bytes of the transaction log records. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_log_buffer_size
item.description: The size in bytes of the buffer that InnoDB uses to write to the log files on disk.

item.name: innodb_log_files_in_group
item.description: The number of log files in the log group. InnoDB writes to the files in a circular fashion.

item.name: innodb_log_file_size
item.description: The size in bytes of each log file in a log group.

item.name: Innodb_log_waits
item.description: The number of times that the log buffer was too small and a wait was required for it to be flushed before continuing.

item.name: Innodb_log_writes
item.description: The number of physical writes to the log file.

item.name: Innodb_log_write_requests
item.description: The number of log write requests.

item.name: Innodb_lsn_current
item.description: Log sequence number as shown in the LOG section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_lsn_flushed
item.description: Flushed up to log sequence number as shown in the LOG section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_lsn_last_checkpoint
item.description: Log sequence number last checkpoint as shown in the LOG section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output.

item.name: Innodb_master_thread_1_second_loops
item.description: As shown in the BACKGROUND THREAD section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_master_thread_10_second_loops
item.description: As shown in the BACKGROUND THREAD section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_master_thread_background_loops
item.description: As shown in the BACKGROUND THREAD section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_master_thread_main_flush_loops
item.description: As shown in the BACKGROUND THREAD section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_master_thread_sleeps
item.description: As shown in the BACKGROUND THREAD section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_max_dirty_pages_pct
item.description: The main thread in InnoDB tries to write pages from the buffer pool so that the percentage of dirty (not yet written) pages will not exceed this value.

item.name: innodb_max_purge_lag
item.description: This variable controls how to delay INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE operations when purge operations are lagging.

item.name: Innodb_max_trx_id
item.description: As shown in the TRANSACTIONS section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_mem_adaptive_hash
item.description: As shown in the BUFFER POOL AND MEMORY section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_mem_dictionary
item.description: As shown in the BUFFER POOL AND MEMORY section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_mem_total
item.description: As shown in the BUFFER POOL AND MEMORY section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_mutex_os_waits
item.description: Mutex OS waits as shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_mutex_spin_rounds
item.description: Mutex spin rounds as shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_mutex_spin_waits
item.description: Mutex spin waits as shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_oldest_view_low_limit_trx_id
item.description: As shown in the TRANSACTIONS section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_old_blocks_pct
item.description: Specifies the approximate percentage of the InnoDB buffer pool used for the old block sublist.

item.name: innodb_old_blocks_time
item.description: Specifies how long in milliseconds (ms) a block inserted into the old sublist must stay there after its first access before it can be moved to the new sublist.

item.name: innodb_open_files
item.description: It specifies the maximum number of .ibd files that MySQL can keep open at one time.

item.name: Innodb_os_log_fsyncs
item.description: The number of fsync() writes done to the log file.

item.name: Innodb_os_log_pending_fsyncs
item.description: The number of pending log file fsync() operations.

item.name: Innodb_os_log_pending_writes
item.description: The number of pending log file writes.

item.name: Innodb_os_log_written
item.description: The number of bytes written to the log file.

item.name: Innodb_pages_created
item.description: The number of pages created.

item.name: Innodb_pages_read
item.description: The number of pages read.

item.name: Innodb_pages_written
item.description: The number of pages written.

item.name: innodb_page_size
item.description: The compiled-in InnoDB page size (default 16KB). Many values are counted in pages; the page size enables them to be easily converted to bytes.

item.name: innodb_purge_batch_size
item.description: Units of redo log records that will trigger a purge operation.

item.name: innodb_purge_threads
item.description: The number of background threads devoted to the InnoDB purge operation.

item.name: Innodb_purge_trx_id
item.description: Purge transaction id as shown in the TRANSACTIONS section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_purge_undo_no
item.description: As shown in the TRANSACTIONS section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_random_read_ahead
item.description: Enables the random read-ahead technique for optimizing InnoDB I/O.

item.name: innodb_read_ahead
item.description: This variable controls the read-ahead algorithm of InnoDB. Only for Percona!

item.name: innodb_read_ahead_threshold
item.description: Controls the sensitivity of linear read-ahead that InnoDB uses to prefetch pages into the buffer pool.

item.name: innodb_read_io_threads
item.description: The number of I/O threads for read operations in InnoDB.

item.name: innodb_recovery_stats
item.description: If set to 1 (0 is default) and recovery is necessary on startup, the server will write detailed recovery statistics to the error log at the end of the recovery process. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_recovery_update_relay_log
item.description: If set to 1 (0 is default), the relay log info file will be overwritten on crash recovery if the information differs from the InnoDB record. Should not be used if multiple storage engine types are being replicated. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_replication_delay
item.description: The replication thread delay (in ms) on a slave server if innodb_thread_concurrency is reached.

item.name: innodb_rollback_on_timeout
item.description: In MySQL 5.5, InnoDB rolls back only the last statement on a transaction timeout by default. If --innodb_rollback_on_timeout is specified, a transaction timeout causes InnoDB to abort and roll back the entire transaction (the same behavior as in MySQL 4.1).

item.name: innodb_rollback_segments
item.description: Defines how many of the rollback segments in the system tablespace that InnoDB uses within a transaction.

item.name: Innodb_rows_deleted
item.description: The number of rows deleted from InnoDB tables.

item.name: Innodb_rows_inserted
item.description: The number of rows inserted into InnoDB tables.

item.name: Innodb_rows_read
item.description: The number of rows read from InnoDB tables.

item.name: Innodb_rows_updated
item.description: The number of rows updated in InnoDB tables.

item.name: Innodb_row_lock_current_waits
item.description: The number of row locks currently being waited for.

item.name: Innodb_row_lock_time
item.description: The total time spent in acquiring row locks, in milliseconds.

item.name: Innodb_row_lock_time_avg
item.description: The average time to acquire a row lock, in milliseconds.

item.name: Innodb_row_lock_time_max
item.description: The maximum time to acquire a row lock, in milliseconds.

item.name: Innodb_row_lock_waits
item.description: The number of times a row lock had to be waited for.

item.name: innodb_show_locks_held
item.description: Specifies the number of locks held for each InnoDB transaction to be displayed in SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_show_verbose_locks
item.description: If set to 1, the traditional InnoDB behavior is followed and locked records will be shown in SHOW INNODB STATUS output. If set to 0, the default, only high-level information about the lock is shown. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_spin_wait_delay
item.description: The maximum delay between polls for a spin lock.

item.name: innodb_stats_auto_update
item.description: If set to 0 (1 is default), index statistics will not be automatically calculated except when an ANALYZE TABLE is run, or the table is first opened. Only for Percona and MariaDB

item.name: innodb_stats_method
item.description: How the server treats NULL values when collecting statistics about the distribution of index values for InnoDB tables.

item.name: innodb_stats_on_metadata
item.description: When this variable is enabled (which is the default, as before the variable was created), InnoDB updates statistics during metadata statements such as SHOW TABLE STATUS or SHOW INDEX, or when accessing the INFORMATION_SCHEMA tables TABLES or STATISTICS.

item.name: innodb_stats_sample_pages
item.description: The number of index pages to sample for index distribution statistics such as are calculated by ANALYZE TABLE.

item.name: innodb_stats_update_need_lock
item.description: Setting to 0 (1 is default) may help reduce contention of the &dict_operation_lock, but also disables the Data_free option in SHOW TABLE STATUS. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_strict_mode
item.description: Whether InnoDB returns errors rather than warnings for certain conditions.

item.name: innodb_support_xa
item.description: Enables InnoDB support for two-phase commit in XA transactions, causing an extra disk flush for transaction preparation.

item.name: innodb_sync_spin_loops
item.description: The number of times a thread waits for an InnoDB mutex to be freed before the thread is suspended.

item.name: Innodb_s_lock_os_waits
item.description: As shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_s_lock_spin_rounds
item.description: As shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_s_lock_spin_waits
item.description: As shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_table_locks
item.description: The default value of innodb_table_locks is 1, which means that LOCK TABLES causes InnoDB to lock a table internally if autocommit = 0.

item.name: innodb_thread_concurrency
item.description: InnoDB tries to keep the number of operating system threads concurrently inside InnoDB less than or equal to the limit given by this variable. Once the number of threads reaches this limit, additional threads are placed into a wait state within a FIFO queue for execution. Threads waiting for locks are not counted in the number of concurrently executing threads.

item.name: innodb_thread_concurrency_timer_based
item.description: If set to 1, thread concurrency will be handled in a lock-free timer-based manner rather than the default mutex-based method. Depends on atomic op builtins being available. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_thread_sleep_delay
item.description: How long InnoDB threads sleep before joining the InnoDB queue, in microseconds.

item.name: Innodb_truncated_status_writes
item.description: Number of times output from SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS has been truncated. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_use_global_flush_log_at_trx_commit
item.description: Determines whether a user can set the variable innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit.

item.name: innodb_use_native_aio
item.description: For Linux systems only, specified whether to use Linux's asynchronous I/O subsystem. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_use_sys_malloc
item.description: Whether InnoDB uses the operating system memory allocator (ON) or its own (OFF).

item.name: innodb_use_sys_stats_table
item.description: If set to 1 (0 is default), XtraDB will use the SYS_STATS system table for extra table index statistics. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: innodb_write_io_threads
item.description: The number of I/O threads for write operations in InnoDB.

item.name: Innodb_x_lock_os_waits
item.description: As shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_x_lock_spin_rounds
item.description: As shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: Innodb_x_lock_spin_waits
item.description: As shown in the SEMAPHORES section of the SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS output. Only for Percona and MariaDB!

item.name: interactive_timeout
item.description: The number of seconds the server waits for activity on an interactive connection before closing it.

item.name: join_buffer_size
item.description: The minimum size of the buffer that is used for plain index scans, range index scans, and joins that do not use indexes and thus perform full table scans.

item.name: Key_blocks_not_flushed
item.description: The number of key blocks in the key cache that have changed but have not yet been flushed to disk.

item.name: Key_blocks_unused
item.description: The number of unused blocks in the key cache.

item.name: Key_blocks_used
item.description: The number of used blocks in the key cache. This value is a high-water mark that indicates the maximum number of blocks that have ever been in use at one time.

item.name: key_buffer_size
item.description: Index blocks for MyISAM tables are buffered and are shared by all threads.

item.name: key_cache_age_threshold
item.description: This value controls the demotion of buffers from the hot sublist of a key cache to the warm sublist.

item.name: key_cache_block_size
item.description: The size in bytes of blocks in the key cache.

item.name: key_cache_division_limit
item.description: The division point between the hot and warm sublists of the key cache buffer list. The value is the percentage of the buffer list to use for the warm sublist.

item.name: Key_reads
item.description: The number of physical reads of a key block from disk.

item.name: Key_read_requests
item.description: The number of requests to read a key block from the cache.

item.name: Key_writes
item.description: The number of physical writes of a key block to disk.

item.name: Key_write_requests
item.description: The number of requests to write a key block to the cache.

item.name: large_files_support
item.description: Whether mysqld was compiled with options for large file support.

item.name: large_pages
item.description: Whether large page support is enabled.

item.name: large_page_size
item.description: If large page support is enabled, this shows the size of memory pages. Currently, large memory pages are supported only on Linux; on other platforms, the value of this variable is always 0.

item.name: local_infile
item.description: Whether LOCAL is supported for LOAD DATA INFILE statements.

item.name: locked_in_memory
item.description: Whether mysqld was locked in memory with --memlock.

item.name: lock_wait_timeout
item.description: This variable specifies the timeout in seconds for attempts to acquire metadata locks.

item.name: log
item.description: This option enables logging to the general query log, which contains entries that record client connections and SQL statements received from clients.

item.name: log_bin
item.description: Status of the binary logging. The server logs all statements that change data to the binary log, which is used for backup and replication.

item.name: log_bin_trust_function_creators
item.description: This option sets the corresponding log_bin_trust_function_creators system variable. If no argument is given, the option sets the variable to 1. log_bin_trust_function_creators affects how MySQL enforces restrictions on stored function and trigger creation.

item.name: log_queries_not_using_indexes
item.description: If you are using this option with the slow query log enabled, queries that are expected to retrieve all rows are logged.

item.name: log_slave_updates
item.description: Whether updates received by a slave server from a master server should be logged to the slave's own binary log.

item.name: log_slow_admin_statements
item.description: When this variable is enabled, administrative statements will be logged to the slow query log. Only for Percona!

item.name: log_slow_filter
item.description: Filters the slow log by the query’s execution plan. Only for Percona!

item.name: log_slow_queries
item.description: Whether slow queries should be logged. “Slow” is determined by the value of the long_query_time variable.

item.name: log_slow_rate_limit
item.description: Specifies that only a fraction of sessions should be logged. Logging is enabled for every nth session. Only for Percona!

item.name: log_slow_slave_statements
item.description: Specifies that slow queries replayed by the slave SQL thread on a MySQL slave will be logged. Only for Percona!

item.name: log_slow_sp_statements
item.description: f TRUE, statements executed by stored procedures are logged to the slow if it is open. Only for Percona!

item.name: log_slow_verbosity
item.description: Specifies how much information to include in your slow log. Only for Percona!

item.name: log_warnings
item.description: Whether to produce additional warning messages to the error log.

item.name: log_warnings_suppress
item.description: When set to the empty string, no warnings are disabled. When set to 1592, warning #1592 messages (unsafe statement for binary logging) are suppressed. Only for Percona!

item.name: long_query_time
item.description: If a query takes longer than this many seconds, the server increments the Slow_queries status variable.

item.name: lower_case_file_system
item.description: This variable describes the case sensitivity of file names on the file system where the data directory is located.

item.name: lower_case_table_names
item.description: If set to 0, table names are stored as specified and comparisons are case sensitive. If set to 1, table names are stored in lowercase on disk and comparisons are not case sensitive. If set to 2, table names are stored as given but compared in lowercase.

item.name: low_priority_updates
item.description: If set to 1, all INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, and LOCK TABLE WRITE statements wait until there is no pending SELECT or LOCK TABLE READ on the affected table.

item.name: max_allowed_packet
item.description: The maximum size of one packet or any generated/intermediate string.

item.name: max_binlog_cache_size
item.description: If a transaction requires more than this many bytes of memory, the server generates a Multi-statement transaction required more than 'max_binlog_cache_size' bytes of storage error.

item.name: max_binlog_size
item.description: If a write to the binary log causes the current log file size to exceed the value of this variable, the server rotates the binary logs (closes the current file and opens the next one).

item.name: max_binlog_stmt_cache_size
item.description: This variable determines maximum of the size of the cache for the binary log to hold nontransactional statements issued during a transaction.

item.name: max_connections
item.description: The maximum permitted number of simultaneous client connections.

item.name: max_connect_errors
item.description: If more than this many successive connection requests from a host are interrupted without a successful connection, the server blocks that host from further connections.

item.name: max_delayed_threads
item.description: Do not start more than this number of threads to handle INSERT DELAYED statements.

item.name: max_error_count
item.description: The maximum number of error, warning, and note messages to be stored for display by the SHOW ERRORS and SHOW WARNINGS statements.

item.name: max_heap_table_size
item.description: This variable sets the maximum size to which user-created MEMORY tables are permitted to grow.

item.name: max_join_size
item.description: Do not permit statements that probably need to examine more than max_join_size rows (for single-table statements) or row combinations (for multiple-table statements) or that are likely to do more than max_join_size disk seeks. By setting this value, you can catch statements where keys are not used properly and that would probably take a long time. Set it if your users tend to perform joins that lack a WHERE clause, that take a long time, or that return millions of rows.

item.name: max_length_for_sort_data
item.description: The cutoff on the size of index values that determines which filesort algorithm to use.

item.name: max_long_data_size
item.description: The maximum size of parameter values that can be sent with the mysql_stmt_send_long_data() C API function.

item.name: max_prepared_stmt_count
item.description: This variable limits the total number of prepared statements in the server.

item.name: max_relay_log_size
item.description: If a write by a replication slave to its relay log causes the current log file size to exceed the value of this variable, the slave rotates the relay logs (closes the current file and opens the next one).

item.name: max_seeks_for_key
item.description: Limit the assumed maximum number of seeks when looking up rows based on a key.

item.name: max_sort_length
item.description: The number of bytes to use when sorting data values. Only the first max_sort_length bytes of each value are used; the rest are ignored.

item.name: max_sp_recursion_depth
item.description: The number of times that any given stored procedure may be called recursively.

item.name: Max_used_connections
item.description: The maximum number of connections that have been in use simultaneously since the server started.

item.name: max_user_connections
item.description: The maximum number of simultaneous connections permitted to any given MySQL user account.

item.name: max_write_lock_count
item.description: After this many write locks, permit some pending read lock requests to be processed in between.

item.name: min_examined_row_limit
item.description: Queries that examine fewer than this number of rows are not logged to the slow query log.

item.name: multi_range_count
item.description: The maximum number of ranges to send to a table handler at once during range selects. This is especially true for the NDBCLUSTER table handler, which needs to send the range requests to all nodes.

item.name: myisam_data_pointer_size
item.description: The default pointer size in bytes, to be used by CREATE TABLE for MyISAM tables when no MAX_ROWS option is specified.

item.name: myisam_max_sort_file_size
item.description: The maximum size of the temporary file that MySQL is permitted to use while re-creating a MyISAM index (during REPAIR TABLE, ALTER TABLE, or LOAD DATA INFILE).

item.name: myisam_mmap_size
item.description: The maximum amount of memory to use for memory mapping compressed MyISAM files.

item.name: myisam_recover_options
item.description: The value of the --myisam-recover option.

item.name: myisam_repair_threads
item.description: If this value is greater than 1, MyISAM table indexes are created in parallel (each index in its own thread) during the Repair by sorting process.

item.name: myisam_sort_buffer_size
item.description: The size of the buffer that is allocated when sorting MyISAM indexes during a REPAIR TABLE or when creating indexes with CREATE INDEX or ALTER TABLE.

item.name: myisam_stats_method
item.description: How the server treats NULL values when collecting statistics about the distribution of index values for MyISAM tables.

item.name: myisam_use_mmap
item.description: Use memory mapping for reading and writing MyISAM tables.

item.name: net_buffer_length
item.description: Each client thread is associated with a connection buffer and result buffer. Both begin with a size given by net_buffer_length but are dynamically enlarged up to max_allowed_packet bytes as needed.

item.name: net_read_timeout
item.description: The number of seconds to wait for more data from a connection before aborting the read.

item.name: net_retry_count
item.description: If a read or write on a communication port is interrupted, retry this many times before giving up.

item.name: net_write_timeout
item.description: The number of seconds to wait for a block to be written to a connection before aborting the write.

item.name: Not_flushed_delayed_rows
item.description: The number of rows waiting to be written in INSERT DELAYED queues.

item.name: old_alter_table
item.description: When this variable is enabled, the server does not use the optimized method of processing an ALTER TABLE operation.

item.name: old_passwords
item.description: This variable controls the password hashing method used by the PASSWORD() function and for the IDENTIFIED BY clause of the CREATE USER and GRANT statements.

item.name: Opened_files
item.description: The number of files that have been opened with my_open() (a mysys library function). Parts of the server that open files without using this function do not increment the count.

item.name: Opened_tables
item.description: The number of tables that have been opened.

item.name: Opened_table_definitions
item.description: The number of .frm files that have been cached.

item.name: Open_files
item.description: The number of files that are open. This count includes regular files opened by the server. It does not include other types of files such as sockets or pipes. Also, the count does not include files that storage engines open using their own internal functions rather than asking the server level to do so.

item.name: open_files_limit
item.description: The number of files that the operating system permits mysqld to open.

item.name: Open_streams
item.description: The number of streams that are open (used mainly for logging).

item.name: Open_tables
item.description: The number of tables that are open.

item.name: Open_table_definitions
item.description: The number of cached .frm files.

item.name: optimizer_prune_level
item.description: Controls the heuristics applied during query optimization to prune less-promising partial plans from the optimizer search space.

item.name: optimizer_search_depth
item.description: The maximum depth of search performed by the query optimizer.

item.name: optimizer_switch
item.description: The engine condition pushdown optimization enables processing for certain comparisons to be “pushed down” to the storage engine level for more efficient execution. Engine condition pushdown is used only by the NDBCLUSTER storage engine.

item.name: port
item.description: The number of the port on which the server listens for TCP/IP connections. This variable can be set with the --port option.

item.name: preload_buffer_size
item.description: The size of the buffer that is allocated when preloading indexes.

item.name: Prepared_stmt_count
item.description: The current number of prepared statements. (The maximum number of statements is given by the max_prepared_stmt_count system variable.)

item.name: profiling
item.description: If set to 0 or OFF (the default), statement profiling is disabled.

item.name: profiling_history_size
item.description: The number of statements for which to maintain profiling information if profiling is enabled.

item.name: protocol_version
item.description: The version of the client/server protocol used by the MySQL server.

item.name: Qcache_free_blocks
item.description: The number of free memory blocks in the query cache.

item.name: Qcache_free_memory
item.description: The amount of free memory for the query cache.

item.name: Qcache_hits
item.description: The number of query cache hits.

item.name: Qcache_inserts
item.description: The number of queries added to the query cache.

item.name: Qcache_lowmem_prunes
item.description: The number of queries that were deleted from the query cache because of low memory.

item.name: Qcache_not_cached
item.description: The number of noncached queries (not cacheable, or not cached due to the query_cache_type setting).

item.name: Qcache_queries_in_cache
item.description: The number of queries registered in the query cache.

item.name: Qcache_total_blocks
item.description: The total number of blocks in the query cache.

item.name: Queries
item.description: The number of statements executed by the server.

item.name: query_alloc_block_size
item.description: The allocation size of memory blocks that are allocated for objects created during statement parsing and execution.

item.name: query_cache_limit
item.description: Do not cache results that are larger than this number of bytes.

item.name: query_cache_min_res_unit
item.description: The minimum size (in bytes) for blocks allocated by the query cache.

item.name: query_cache_size
item.description: The amount of memory allocated for caching query results.

item.name: query_cache_strip_comments
item.description: Makes the server ignore comments when checking for a query cache hit. Only for Percona!

item.name: query_cache_type
item.description: Set the query cache type.

item.name: query_cache_wlock_invalidate
item.description: Normally, when one client acquires a WRITE lock on a MyISAM table, other clients are not blocked from issuing statements that read from the table if the query results are present in the query cache. Setting this variable to 1 causes acquisition of a WRITE lock for a table to invalidate any queries in the query cache that refer to the table.

item.name: query_prealloc_size
item.description: The size of the persistent buffer used for statement parsing and execution.

item.name: query_response_time_range_base
item.description: Sets up the logarithm base for the scale. Only for Percona!

item.name: query_response_time_stats
item.description: This variable enables and disables collection of query times if the feature is available in the server that’s running. If the value of variable have_response_time_distribution is YES, then you can enable collection of query times by setting this variable to ON using SET GLOBAL. Only for Percona!

item.name: Questions
item.description: The number of statements executed by the server. This includes only statements sent to the server by clients and not statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Queries variable. This variable does not count COM_PING, COM_STATISTICS, COM_STMT_PREPARE, COM_STMT_CLOSE, or COM_STMT_RESET commands.

item.name: range_alloc_block_size
item.description: The size of blocks that are allocated when doing range optimization.

item.name: read_buffer_size
item.description: Each thread that does a sequential scan for a MyISAM table allocates a buffer of this size (in bytes) for each table it scans.

item.name: read_only
item.description: This variable is off by default. When it is enabled, the server permits no updates except from users that have the SUPER privilege or (on a slave server) from updates performed by slave threads. In replication setups, it can be useful to enable read_only on slave servers to ensure that slaves accept updates only from the master server and not from clients.

trigger.name: MySQL server is in "Read only" mode

item.name: read_rnd_buffer_size
item.description: When reading rows from a MyISAM table in sorted order following a key-sorting operation, the rows are read through this buffer to avoid disk seeks.

item.name: relay_log_purge
item.description: Disables or enables automatic purging of relay log files as soon as they are not needed any more. The default value is 1 (ON).

item.name: relay_log_recovery
item.description: Enables automatic relay log recovery immediately following server startup, which means that the replication slave discards all unprocessed relay logs and retrieves them from the replication master.

item.name: relay_log_space_limit
item.description: This option places an upper limit on the total size in bytes of all relay logs on the slave.

item.name: report_port
item.description: The TCP/IP port number for connecting to the slave, to be reported to the master during slave registration.

item.name: secure_auth
item.description: If this variable is enabled, the server blocks connections by clients that attempt to use accounts that have passwords stored in the old (pre-4.1) format.

item.name: Select_full_join
item.description: The number of joins that perform table scans because they do not use indexes. If this value is not 0, you should carefully check the indexes of your tables.

item.name: Select_full_range_join
item.description: The number of joins that used a range search on a reference table.

item.name: Select_range
item.description: The number of joins that used ranges on the first table.

item.name: Select_range_check
item.description: The number of joins without keys that check for key usage after each row.

item.name: Select_scan
item.description: The number of joins that did a full scan of the first table.

item.name: server_id
item.description: The server ID, used in replication to give each master and slave a unique identity.

trigger.name: MySQL server ID has been changed

item.name: skip_external_locking
item.description: This is OFF if mysqld uses external locking (system locking), ON if external locking is disabled. This affects only MyISAM table access.

item.name: skip_name_resolve
item.description: If it is ON, mysqld resolves host names when checking client connections. If OFF, mysqld uses only IP numbers and all Host column values in the grant tables must be IP addresses or localhost.

item.name: skip_networking
item.description: This is ON if the server permits only local (non-TCP/IP) connections. On Unix, local connections use a Unix socket file. On Windows, local connections use a named pipe or shared memory.

item.name: skip_show_database
item.description: This prevents people from using the SHOW DATABASES statement if they do not have the SHOW DATABASES privilege.

item.name: slave_compressed_protocol
item.description: Whether to use compression of the slave/master protocol if both the slave and the master support it.

item.name: slave_exec_mode
item.description: Controls whether IDEMPOTENT or STRICT mode is used in replication conflict resolution and error checking.

item.name: Slave_heartbeat_period
item.description: Shows the replication heartbeat interval (in seconds) on a replication slave.

item.name: slave_net_timeout
item.description: The number of seconds to wait for more data from a master/slave connection before aborting the read.

item.name: Slave_open_temp_tables
item.description: The number of temporary tables that the slave SQL thread currently has open.

item.name: Slave_received_heartbeats
item.description: This counter increments with each replication heartbeat received by a replication slave since the last time that the slave was restarted or reset, or a CHANGE MASTER TO statement was issued.

item.name: Slave_retried_transactions
item.description: The total number of times since startup that the replication slave SQL thread has retried transactions.

item.name: Slave_running
item.description: This is ON if this server is a replication slave that is connected to a replication master, and both the I/O and SQL threads are running; otherwise, it is OFF.

item.name: slave_skip_errors
item.description: Normally, replication stops when an error occurs on the slave. This gives you the opportunity to resolve the inconsistency in the data manually. This variable tells the slave SQL thread to continue replication when a statement returns any of the errors listed in the variable value.

item.name: slave_transaction_retries
item.description: If a replication slave SQL thread fails to execute a transaction because of an InnoDB deadlock or because the transaction's execution time exceeded InnoDB's innodb_lock_wait_timeout or NDBCLUSTER's TransactionDeadlockDetectionTimeout or TransactionInactiveTimeout, it automatically retries slave_transaction_retries times before stopping with an error.

item.name: slave_type_conversions
item.description: Controls the type conversion mode in effect on the slave when using MySQL Cluster Replication.

item.name: Slow_launch_threads
item.description: The number of threads that have taken more than slow_launch_time seconds to create.

item.name: slow_launch_time
item.description: If creating a thread takes longer than this many seconds, the server increments the Slow_launch_threads status variable.

item.name: Slow_queries
item.description: The number of queries that have taken more than long_query_time seconds.

item.name: slow_query_log
item.description: Whether the slow query log is enabled.

item.name: slow_query_log_timestamp_always
item.description: If TRUE, a timestamp is printed on every slow log record. Multiple records may have the same time. Only Percona!

item.name: slow_query_log_timestamp_precision
item.description: Time precision of slow query log format. Only for Percona!

item.name: slow_query_log_use_global_control
item.description: Specifies which variables have global scope instead of local. Only for Percona!

item.name: sort_buffer_size
item.description: Each session that needs to do a sort allocates a buffer of this size.

item.name: Sort_merge_passes
item.description: The number of merge passes that the sort algorithm has had to do.

item.name: Sort_range
item.description: The number of sorts that were done using ranges.

item.name: Sort_rows
item.description: The number of sorted rows.

item.name: Sort_scan
item.description: The number of sorts that were done by scanning the table.

item.name: sql_auto_is_null
item.description: If this variable is set to 1, then after a statement that successfully inserts an automatically generated AUTO_INCREMENT value.

item.name: sql_buffer_result
item.description: If set to 1, sql_buffer_result forces results from SELECT statements to be put into temporary tables.

item.name: sql_log_bin
item.description: This variable controls whether logging to the binary log is done.

item.name: sql_log_off
item.description: This variable controls whether logging to the general query log is done.

item.name: sql_mode
item.description: The current server SQL mode, which can be set dynamically.

item.name: sql_notes
item.description: If set to 1 (the default), warnings of Note level increment warning_count and the server records them.

item.name: sql_quote_show_create
item.description: If set to 1 (the default), the server quotes identifiers for SHOW CREATE TABLE and SHOW CREATE DATABASE statements.

item.name: sql_safe_updates
item.description: If set to 1, MySQL aborts UPDATE or DELETE statements that do not use a key in the WHERE clause or a LIMIT clause.

item.name: sql_select_limit
item.description: The maximum number of rows to return from SELECT statements.

item.name: sql_slave_skip_counter
item.description: The number of events from the master that a slave server should skip.

item.name: sql_warnings
item.description: This variable controls whether single-row INSERT statements produce an information string if warnings occur.

item.name: storage_engine
item.description: The default storage engine (table type).

item.name: sync_binlog
item.description: If the value of this variable is greater than 0, the MySQL server synchronizes its binary log to disk (using fdatasync()) after every sync_binlog writes to the binary log.

item.name: sync_frm
item.description: If this variable is set to 1, when any nontemporary table is created its .frm file is synchronized to disk (using fdatasync()). This is slower but safer in case of a crash. The default is 1.

item.name: sync_master_info
item.description: If the value of this variable is greater than 0, a replication slave synchronizes its master.info file to disk (using fdatasync()) after every sync_master_info events.

item.name: sync_relay_log
item.description: If the value of this variable is greater than 0, the MySQL server synchronizes its relay log to disk (using fdatasync()) after every sync_relay_log writes to the relay log.

item.name: sync_relay_log_info
item.description: If the value of this variable is greater than 0, a replication slave synchronizes its relay-log.info file to disk (using fdatasync()) after every sync_relay_log_info transactions.

item.name: system_time_zone
item.description: The server system time zone. When the server begins executing, it inherits a time zone setting from the machine defaults, possibly modified by the environment of the account used for running the server or the startup script.

item.name: table_definition_cache
item.description: The number of table definitions (from .frm files) that can be stored in the definition cache.

item.name: Table_locks_immediate
item.description: The number of times that a request for a table lock could be granted immediately.

item.name: Table_locks_waited
item.description: The number of times that a request for a table lock could not be granted immediately and a wait was needed.

item.name: table_open_cache
item.description: The number of open tables for all threads. Increasing this value increases the number of file descriptors that mysqld requires.

item.name: Tc_log_page_size
item.description: The page size used for the memory-mapped implementation of the XA recovery log.

item.name: Tc_log_page_waits
item.description: For the memory-mapped implementation of the recovery log, this variable increments each time the server was not able to commit a transaction and had to wait for a free page in the log.

item.name: Threads_cached
item.description: The number of threads in the thread cache.

item.name: Threads_connected
item.description: The number of currently open connections.

item.name: Threads_created
item.description: The number of threads created to handle connections.

item.name: Threads_running
item.description: The number of threads that are not sleeping.

item.name: thread_cache_size
item.description: How many threads the server should cache for reuse.

item.name: thread_concurrency
item.description: This variable is specific to Solaris systems, for which mysqld invokes the thr_setconcurrency() with the variable value. This function enables applications to give the threads system a hint about the desired number of threads that should be run at the same time.

item.name: thread_handling
item.description: The thread-handling model used by the server for connection threads.

item.name: thread_stack
item.description: The stack size for each thread.

item.name: timed_mutexes
item.description: This variable controls whether InnoDB mutexes are timed.

item.name: time_zone
item.description: The current time zone. This variable is used to initialize the time zone for each client that connects.

item.name: tmp_table_size
item.description: The maximum size of internal in-memory temporary tables. The actual limit is determined as the minimum of tmp_table_size and max_heap_table_size.

item.name: transaction_alloc_block_size
item.description: The amount in bytes by which to increase a per-transaction memory pool which needs memory.

item.name: transaction_prealloc_size
item.description: There is a per-transaction memory pool from which various transaction-related allocations take memory. The initial size of the pool in bytes is transaction_prealloc_size. For every allocation that cannot be satisfied from the pool because it has insufficient memory available, the pool is increased by transaction_alloc_block_size bytes. When the transaction ends, the pool is truncated to transaction_prealloc_size bytes.

item.name: tx_isolation
item.description: The default transaction isolation level.

item.name: unique_checks
item.description: If set to 1 (the default), uniqueness checks for secondary indexes in InnoDB tables are performed. If set to 0, storage engines are permitted to assume that duplicate keys are not present in input data. If you know for certain that your data does not contain uniqueness violations, you can set this to 0 to speed up large table imports to InnoDB.

item.name: updatable_views_with_limit
item.description: This variable controls whether updates to a view can be made when the view does not contain all columns of the primary key defined in the underlying table, if the update statement contains a LIMIT clause.

item.name: Uptime
item.description: The number of seconds that the server has been up.

item.name: Uptime_since_flush_status
item.description: The number of seconds since the most recent FLUSH STATUS statement.

item.name: userstat
item.description: Enables or disables collection of statistics. Only for Percona server!

item.name: version
item.description: The version number for the server.

item.name: wait_timeout
item.description: The number of seconds the server waits for activity on a noninteractive connection before closing it.

item.name: MySQL $5
item.description: http://www.percona.com/doc/percona-monitoring-plugins/cacti/mysql-templates.html

item.name: MySQL $5
item.description: http://www.percona.com/doc/percona-monitoring-plugins/cacti/mysql-templates.html

trigger.name: MySQL clients are using more than 90% available connections

trigger.expression: {Template App MySQL advanced:mysql[query_cache_type].last(0)}=1 and {Template App MySQL advanced:mysql[Qcache_free_memory].max(#3)}<4M and {Template App MySQL advanced:mysql[query_cache_size].last(0)}>64M
trigger.name: MySQL Server query cache has not enough free space
